When you're looking for Craftsman Pro riding lawn mower repair services or lawn tractor repair, Sears Home Services can help.
We're your best option for quick and easy local service and repair of your Craftsman Pro riding lawn mower or lawn tractor. We've done hundreds of thousands of lawn equipment repairs, so you can count on the small engine repair experts from Sears to identify the problem and know the solution.
How much does it cost to repair a Craftsman Pro riding mower?
Craftsman Pro riding mower repairs typically range from $220 to $650 depending on where you live and the cost of labor and parts required.
The most common repairs on a Craftsman Pro riding mower are:

Replacing an interlock switch.
Installing new mandrel pulleys.
Replacing the starter solenoid.

Although you may be able to replace these parts on your own, diagnosing the problem can be challenging. That’s why it’s important to have a qualified repair technician come out to inspect your Craftsman Pro riding mower.
How to save money on a Craftsman Pro riding mower repair
Fixing a riding mower can sometimes be costly. Here are some tips to help you manage lawn equipment repair and replacement costs.

Find a reputable service provider. Look for a service company with high ratings in customer reviews. Make sure that the service provider’s technicians are authorized to complete repairs on your equipment.
Get a repair protection agreement. Save on lawn equipment repairs by investing in an extended warranty like a repair protection agreement, which can help cover repair and replacement costs and provide peace of mind.
Choose Sears Home Services as your lawn equipment repair provider. We service lawn equipment and appliances in an average of 3,000,000+ homes each year, earning over 600,000 5-star ratings with our experienced technicians.

Common Craftsman Pro Riding Lawn Mower Issues

Riding mower won't start
Riding mower won't stay running
Riding mower or tractor has unusual and excessive vibration
Riding mower is bagging, discharging, or mulching improperly
Riding mower is leaking oil

Common Craftsman Pro Riding Lawn Mower Repairs

Replacing spark plugs and spark plug wires
Replacing the air filter
Inspecting and cleaning the fuel filter
Cleaning the carburetor
Mower blade inspection and blade sharpening

Our repair experts are some of the best riding lawn mower and riding tractor repair service technicians in the business. Technicians that are local, licensed and vetted, with the skills to get your Craftsman Pro riding mower or lawn tractor up and running quickly.
Schedule your riding mower repair online today.
If your Craftsman Pro riding mower doesn't need a repair, but simply a tune-up or pre-season maintenance, schedule riding mower maintenance with our technicians today.
Find the parts and accessories you need to keep your riding mower in top shape at Sears PartsDirect.Frequently Asked QuestionsHow quickly can I schedule Craftsman Pro riding mower repair?In many areas, Sears Home Services offers same-day or next-day Craftsman Pro riding mower repair appointments. Enter your zip code in the scheduler to check availability in your neighborhood.What are common Craftsman Pro riding mower problems Sears can fix?Our experts can diagnose and fix a variety of riding mower issues, including:

Mower won’t start or stay running
Blades not engaging or cutting unevenly
Steering or drive problems
Battery, spark plug, or fuel system failures
Belt or pulley damage
Smoke from the engine or excessive noise

No matter the issue, we’ll get your riding mower back in working order quickly.Does Sears repair Craftsman Pro riding mowers that are out of warranty?Absolutely. Sears Home Services repairs riding lawn mowers whether they’re under warranty or not. Our technicians can service older models because we have sources for genuine Craftsman Pro replacement parts.What types of riding mowers do you service?Sears Home Services repairs and maintains these types of riding mowers:

Front-engine riding mowers.
Lawn tractors and yard tractors.
Zero-turn riding mowers.
Rear-engine riding mowers.
Wide-deck ride-on mowers.

When you're looking for Craftsman Pro riding lawn mower repair services or lawn tractor repair, Sears Home Services can help.
We're your best option for quick and easy local service and repair of your Craftsman Pro riding lawn mower or lawn tractor. We've done hundreds of thousands of lawn equipment repairs, so you can count on the small engine repair experts from Sears to identify the problem and know the solution.
How much does it cost to repair a Craftsman Pro riding mower?
Craftsman Pro riding mower repairs typically range from $220 to $650 depending on where you live and the cost of labor and parts required.
The most common repairs on a Craftsman Pro riding mower are:

Replacing an interlock switch.
Installing new mandrel pulleys.
Replacing the starter solenoid.

Although you may be able to replace these parts on your own, diagnosing the problem can be challenging. That’s why it’s important to have a qualified repair technician come out to inspect your Craftsman Pro riding mower.
How to save money on a Craftsman Pro riding mower repair
Fixing a riding mower can sometimes be costly. Here are some tips to help you manage lawn equipment repair and replacement costs.

Find a reputable service provider. Look for a service company with high ratings in customer reviews. Make sure that the service provider’s technicians are authorized to complete repairs on your equipment.
Get a repair protection agreement. Save on lawn equipment repairs by investing in an extended warranty like a repair protection agreement, which can help cover repair and replacement costs and provide peace of mind.
Choose Sears Home Services as your lawn equipment repair provider. We service lawn equipment and appliances in an average of 3,000,000+ homes each year, earning over 600,000 5-star ratings with our experienced technicians.

Common Craftsman Pro Riding Lawn Mower Issues

Riding mower won't start
Riding mower won't stay running
Riding mower or tractor has unusual and excessive vibration
Riding mower is bagging, discharging, or mulching improperly
Riding mower is leaking oil

Common Craftsman Pro Riding Lawn Mower Repairs

Replacing spark plugs and spark plug wires
Replacing the air filter
Inspecting and cleaning the fuel filter
Cleaning the carburetor
Mower blade inspection and blade sharpening

Our repair experts are some of the best riding lawn mower and riding tractor repair service technicians in the business. Technicians that are local, licensed and vetted, with the skills to get your Craftsman Pro riding mower or lawn tractor up and running quickly.
Schedule your riding mower repair online today.
If your Craftsman Pro riding mower doesn't need a repair, but simply a tune-up or pre-season maintenance, schedule riding mower maintenance with our technicians today.
Find the parts and accessories you need to keep your riding mower in top shape at Sears PartsDirect.Frequently Asked QuestionsHow quickly can I schedule Craftsman Pro riding mower repair?In many areas, Sears Home Services offers same-day or next-day Craftsman Pro riding mower repair appointments. Enter your zip code in the scheduler to check availability in your neighborhood.What are common Craftsman Pro riding mower problems Sears can fix?Our experts can diagnose and fix a variety of riding mower issues, including:

Mower won’t start or stay running
Blades not engaging or cutting unevenly
Steering or drive problems
Battery, spark plug, or fuel system failures
Belt or pulley damage
Smoke from the engine or excessive noise

No matter the issue, we’ll get your riding mower back in working order quickly.Does Sears repair Craftsman Pro riding mowers that are out of warranty?Absolutely. Sears Home Services repairs riding lawn mowers whether they’re under warranty or not. Our technicians can service older models because we have sources for genuine Craftsman Pro replacement parts.What types of riding mowers do you service?Sears Home Services repairs and maintains these types of riding mowers:

Front-engine riding mowers.
Lawn tractors and yard tractors.
Zero-turn riding mowers.
Rear-engine riding mowers.
Wide-deck ride-on mowers.

Book online in less than a minute.DIAGNOSTIC FEE
Apply your diagnostic fee to the costs of repair.PROTECTION PLANS

It ensures technicians understand refrigerant types, environmental impact, and proper handling techniques.What is a Compressor?A compressor is a mechanical device that increases the pressure of a gas by reducing its volume, essential in various systems including refrigerators, air conditioners, and HVAC units for cooling and refrigeration processes.What is a Condenser?A condenser is a component of HVAC and refrigeration systems, responsible for releasing absorbed heat from the refrigerant into the outside air or a water line, thus facilitating the cooling process.

Mower won’t start or stay running
Blades not engaging or cutting unevenly
Steering or drive problems
Battery, spark plug, or fuel system failures

Smoke from the engine or excessive noise

Lawn tractors and yard tractors.

Wide-deck ride-on mowers.

full_content.content: Glossary TermsWhat is the drum of the washing machine?The drum is the core part of the washer that holds your laundry and enables the cleaning process through rotation, agitation, and rinsing.What is a 608 Certification?The 608 Certification, mandated by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), is required for HVAC technicians to legally handle refrigerants. It ensures technicians understand refrigerant types, environmental impact, and proper handling techniques.What is a Compressor?A compressor is a mechanical device that increases the pressure of a gas by reducing its volume, essential in various systems including refrigerators, air conditioners, and HVAC units for cooling and refrigeration processes.What is a Condenser?A condenser is a component of HVAC and refrigeration systems, responsible for releasing absorbed heat from the refrigerant into the outside air or a water line, thus facilitating the cooling process.

self.__next_f.push([1,"Is your Craftsman Pro riding mower not working?

When you're looking for Craftsman Pro riding lawn mower repair services or lawn tractor repair, Sears Home Services can help.

We're your best option for quick and easy local service and repair of your Craftsman Pro riding lawn mower or lawn tractor. We've done hundreds of thousands of lawn equipment repairs, so you can count on the small engine repair experts from Sears to identify the problem and know the solution.

## How much does it cost to repair a Craftsman Pro riding mower?

Craftsman Pro riding mower repairs typically range from __$220 to $650__ depending on where you live and the cost of labor and parts required. 

The most common repairs on a Craftsman Pro riding mower are:

* Replacing an interlock switch.
* Installing new mandrel pulleys.
* [Replacing the starter solenoid](https://youtu.be/Xs3nd67ESPM). 

Although you may be able to replace these parts on your own, diagnosing the problem can be challenging. That’s why it’s important to have a qualified repair technician come out to inspect your Craftsman Pro riding mower.

## How to save money on a Craftsman Pro riding mower repair

Fixing a riding mower can sometimes be costly. Here are some tips to help you manage lawn equipment repair and replacement costs. 

* __Find a reputable service provider.__ Look for a service company with high ratings in customer reviews. Make sure that the service provider’s technicians are authorized to complete repairs on your equipment.
* __Get a repair protection agreement.__ Save on lawn equipment repairs by investing in an extended warranty like a [repair protection agreement](https://www.sears.com/en_us/dap/sears-protection-agreements.html), which can help cover repair and replacement costs and provide peace of mind. 
* __Choose Sears Home Services as your lawn equipment repair provider.__ We service lawn equipment and appliances in an average of 3,000,000+ homes each year, earning over 600,000 5-star ratings with our experienced technicians.

### Common Craftsman Pro Riding Lawn Mower Issues

- Riding mower won't start
- Riding mower won't stay running
- Riding mower or tractor has unusual and excessive vibration
- Riding mower is bagging, discharging, or mulching improperly
- Riding mower is leaking oil

### Common Craftsman Pro Riding Lawn Mower Repairs

- Replacing spark plugs and spark plug wires
- Replacing the air filter
- Inspecting and cleaning the fuel filter
- Cleaning the carburetor
- Mower blade inspection and blade sharpening

Our repair experts are some of the best riding lawn mower and riding tractor repair service technicians in the business. Technicians that are local, licensed and vetted, with the skills to get your Craftsman Pro riding mower or lawn tractor up and running quickly.

[Schedule your riding mower repair online today.](/scheduler/shs?serviceType=R&productName=Riding%20Mower)

If your Craftsman Pro riding mower doesn't need a repair, but simply a tune-up or pre-season maintenance, schedule [riding mower maintenance](/maintain/riding-lawn-mower) with our technicians today.

Find the parts and accessories you need to keep your riding mower in top shape at [Sears PartsDirect](https://www.searspartsdirect.com/category/1234652/riding-mowers-tractors-parts)."])

self.__next_f.push([1,"## Understanding the Starting System

The starting system of a riding mower includes the battery, ignition circuit, starter motor, and spark plug. All these parts work in unison to kick-start your mower's engine. If your lawn mower won't start, it could be due to a weak or dead battery, a faulty ignition switch, failed component in the ignition circuit, a worn-out starter motor, or a malfunctioning spark plug. Our guide aims to help you understand these parts better and address the most common issues effectively. 

---

## Troubleshooting: Why Won't my Riding Mower Start?

Here are some simple steps to help you diagnose and fix common issues that could be the answer to 'why won’t my riding mower start?'.

### 1. Check the Battery and Connections 

Ensure the battery is fully charged and correctly connected. Look for corrosion on the battery terminals and damage on the battery cables. Clean or replace as necessary.

### 2. Inspect the Spark Plug and Ignition System 

Check the spark plug for fouling or damage. Examine the ignition switch and wiring for loose connections or damage. Clean, repair, or replace the ignition switch as required. Here’s a DIY video that shows how to troubleshoot the entire ignition system:

<iframe width="660" height="371" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/OVqOfSzEQkw" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

### 3. Examine the Fuel System and Carburetor

Confirm there's enough fresh fuel in the tank. Check the fuel filter and carburetor for blockages or damage. Clean, repair, or replace as needed.

Here’s a helpful DIY video that shows how to check the fuel system in a common riding mower:

<iframe width="660" height="371" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/RYYcJR8fgaY" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

If you've followed these steps and your lawn mower will not start, it may be time to seek professional assistance.

---

## Maintaining Your Mower's Performance

Regular maintenance can prevent your lawn mower from not starting and extend its lifespan. Establishing a maintenance schedule as per manufacturer's guidelines, cleaning and lubricating key parts, and proper storage are all crucial.

* __Routine maintenance:__ Regular maintenance tasks may include oil changes, air filter replacement, spark plug checks, and belt and blade inspections. Following a [consistent routine](https://www.searspartsdirect.com/diy/article/how-to-tune-up-a-riding-lawn-mower-video) helps identify potential problems early and prevent instances where your lawn mower won't start.
* __Cleaning and lubrication:__ Remove debris from the mower deck to prevent airflow obstruction and overheating. Lubricate moving parts like wheel bearings and blade spindles to reduce friction and ensure smooth operation.
* __Proper storage:__ If storing your mower for an extended period, drain the fuel tank or add a fuel stabilizer. Disconnect the battery and store it in a cool, dry place. Protect your mower from weather damage with a cover or by storing it in a covered area.

By adhering to these maintenance tips, you can keep your riding mower in top condition and prevent instances where you wonder 'why won’t my riding mower start?'. Always consult your owner's manual for specific instructions and prioritize safety when performing maintenance tasks.

---"])

self.__next_f.push([1,"## What is a Voltage Meter?

A voltage meter measures the electrical potential difference (voltage) between two points in an electrical circuit. 

Most voltage meters include modes for measuring electrical resistance and current so they’re commonly called multimeters. 

The voltage mode on a multimeter can measure these 2 different types of electrical voltage:

* __DC Voltage__ -- For direct current (DC) systems, such as batteries, lawn & garden equipment such as riding mowers and automotive circuits.
* __AC Voltage__ -- For alternating current (AC) systems, like household outlets and home appliances.

---

## How Does a Voltage Meter Work?

A voltage meter measures how much voltage passes between two points in an electrical circuit. 

It does this by determining the difference between the positive input of voltage and the negative input of voltage. Here's how it works:

### Probe Connection

The voltage meter has two probes: a red probe for the positive terminal and a black probe for the negative terminal (ground).

When connected to a circuit, it forms a low-resistance path for current to flow momentarily.

### Voltage Measurement

The meter detects the potential difference (voltage) between the two points where the probes are connected.

This difference is displayed on the screen in volts (V).

### Safety

Most meters have built-in overload protection to prevent damage if accidentally connected to a voltage higher than its capacity.

---

## How to Use a Voltage Meter in a Riding Lawn Mower 12-Volt DC System 

A 12-volt DC battery powers the electrical system powers many lawn tractors. The battery sends current to various electrical components such as the starter, lights, and ignition system. 

Here's how to use a voltage meter to measure and diagnose problems in a DC system:

### Wear Gloves and Safety Goggles

Wear insulated safety gloves and protective eye goggles when checking voltage in a riding mower. 

Turn off the riding mower engine if you don’t need it running when checking voltage.

Avoid contact with moving parts, wiring and adjacent metallic surfaces when taking voltage readings.

### Set the Meter

Turn the multimeter on and set it to measure DC voltage. Ensure the meter voltage range is properly (at least up to 20V) for a 12V system riding mower electrical system.

### Test the Battery

When troubleshooting riding mower electrical problems, you’ll typically need to test the battery using a voltage meter to determine whether the battery has an adequate charge to supply current through the riding mower electrical system.

To check the battery’s charge, connect the meter red probe to the battery's positive terminal (+) and the black probe to the negative terminal (-).

A healthy 12V battery should read between 12.4V and 12.6V when fully charged.

If the voltage is below 12V, the battery needs charging or replacement.

### Testing Specific Riding Mower Circuits

Most of the time, you’ll reach for a voltage meter to test circuits and components in your riding mower when it won’t start. Checking for voltage at specific points in a circuit will tell you whether a fuse is blown, a switch is bad or a component has failed.

To see specific examples of how to use a voltage meter to diagnose a common starting problem in a riding lawn mower, view this popular DIY video:

<iframe width="660" height="371" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/A8m88LawN0I" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

When you’re unable to diagnose and fix a riding mower starting problem on your own, schedule [riding mower repair](/repair/riding-mower-repair-service) service and we’ll send a Sears Home Services technician to your home to fix the starting issue.

---

## Using a Voltage Meter with Household Appliances

Although professional service technicians often use a voltage meter to diagnose and repair home appliances, DIY’ers should only use electrical resistance settings on the meter to check for problems and failed components in AC circuits.

You should __always unplug__ a home appliance to disconnect electrical power before disassembling and diagnosing or repairing a failure.

Checking live voltage in an appliance is extremely dangerous for DIY’ers because making contact with electrically energized components or wiring inside the appliance can result in lethal electrical shocks.

Here’s a video that shows how to use a multimeter to safely check resistance through circuits and components in an appliance to diagnose a failure:

<iframe width="660" height="371" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/R6DgIA_ikQQ" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Here’s a popular DIY troubleshooting video that shows details of how to use a multimeter to check circuits and components in a clothes dryer that won’t heat:

<iframe width="660" height="371" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/VTnDslKW6y0" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

If you’re unable to diagnose and repair an appliance failure on your own using resistance measurements, schedule [appliance repair](/repair) service and we’ll send a Sears Home Services technician to your home to fix the problem.

---

## Safety Tips When Using a Voltage Meter

Follow these safety tips when using a voltage meter:

* __Double-Check the Meter Settings:__ Always confirm the meter is set to the correct mode (DC or AC), measurement setting and range.
* __Inspect Probes and Leads:__ Look for damage that could compromise safety. Replace probes if wiring or insulation is damaged.
* __Wears Proper Protective Equipment:__ When checking DC voltage in riding mowers, wear insulated gloves and protective eye goggles. When disassembling and checking resistance in appliances, wear work gloves to protect your hands from sharp edges inside appliances.
* __Avoid Short Circuits:__ Keep probes from touching each other and other live wires or components while checking live DC circuits in riding mowers.
* __Disconnect Electrical Power from Appliances:__ Never check live AC voltage in appliances. Unplug the appliance power cord before disassembling and using a multimeter to check resistance in appliances to diagnose failures.
* __Follow the Manual:__ Always consult your voltage meter's user manual for specific instructions.

---

Understanding how to __safely__ use a voltage meter can save you time and money while giving you the confidence to tackle basic electrical repairs. 

Whether you're testing a 12-volt system in a lawn tractor or diagnosing a failure in a household appliance, mastering this tool will empower your DIY projects. 

With proper safety precautions in place, a reliable voltage meter can be your go-to device for troubleshooting and maintenance.

---"])

self.__next_f.push([1,"### How to determine what’s wrong with your mower, and if it’s a DIY fix or a job for a repairman.

With spring in full swing, it’s time to rev up your [riding lawn mower](/repair/riding-mower-repair-service). But like any piece of machinery, riding mowers don’t always work like they should, especially after a long winter’s storage.

Here are five common [riding mower problems](/blog/reasons-why-your-riding-mower-wont-start) Sears technicians typically see, and what you should do about them.

## Problem #1: The Engine Cranks But Doesn’t Start
- **Likely Culprit**: Old fuel, spark plug corrosion, dirty air filter, or ignition switch issues.
  - **DIY Fixes**:
    - Replace old fuel with fresh gasoline.
    - Inspect the spark plug for corrosion and replace if necessary.
    - Check the air filter and clean or replace it if it's dirty.
    - Use starting fluid as a last resort if the engine still won’t start.
  - **Technician Needed**: If the issue persists after these checks, the ignition switch might be faulty and require professional attention.

## Problem #2: Your Engine Turns Over But Dies Quickly
- **Likely Culprit**: Battery issues, malfunctioning seat switch, or electrical shorts.
  - **DIY Fixes**:
    - Charge the battery for 24 hours and retry.
    - Ensure the seat switch is properly connected.
  - **Technician Needed**: If the engine continues to die or the seat switch is correctly plugged in, the switch may need replacement or there could be an electrical short needing expert diagnosis.

## Problem #3: The Engine Rattles and Hums
- **Likely Culprit**: Worn fan belt, the need for motor lubrication, or loose parts.
  - **DIY Fixes**:
    - Inspect the fan belt for wear and tear and replace if necessary.
    - Lubricate the motor according to the manufacturer's instructions.
    - Tighten any loose parts that could cause vibration.
  - **Technician Needed**: If the problem persists or you’re unsure about the source of the noise, professional servicing may be required to pinpoint and solve the issue.

## Problem #4: It Runs Roughly
- **Likely Culprit**: Clogged carburetor or damaged flywheel key.
  - **DIY Fixes**:
    - Inspecting and possibly replacing the carburetor if it is clogged.
    - If the rough running started after an impact (like hitting a rock), check the flywheel key for damage and replace if necessary.
  - **Technician Needed**: Carburetor issues and flywheel key damage can be complex, requiring specific tools and expertise for proper handling.

## Problem #5: It Doesn’t Cut the Grass
- **Likely Culprit**: Worn or cracked blade belt.
  - **DIY Fixes**:
    - Inspect the blade belt for any signs of wear or cracks and replace it as needed.
  - **Technician Needed**: If replacing the blade belt doesn't solve the problem, or if there's uncertainty in identifying belt issues, professional service can ensure the mower is properly fixed and safe to use.

For any issues beyond simple DIY fixes, [schedule repair](/scheduler/shs?serviceType=R) with a professional technician to ensure your engine or mower is repaired safely and effectively. Whether it's a persistent problem that DIY steps haven't fixed or a complex issue requiring specialized knowledge, expert assistance can get your equipment back in top condition.
"])

self.__next_f.push([1,"**Are you ready to prepare your yard for summer? View our infographic for the best summer lawn care, including tips on watering, mowing and what to plant now.**

You don’t want to be that neighbor, the one with the overgrown lawn and unkempt garden that make everyone scowl as they drive by. There’s an art to creating a beautiful landscape around your home, but you don’t need to be a professional to do it. All it takes is a little TLC and some know-how.

There are the basics that go into grass care in summer, including mowing and watering, weeding, mulching and keeping pests at bay. But there are some things you can do to really damage your yard. Watering too much, for example, could turn your lawn into the Black Lagoon. Not keeping a handle on weeds can quickly escalate to an infestation. And skipping mulch might be depriving your garden of a powerhouse player.

So grab your garden shears, don a pair of work gloves, and get out there and enjoy the summer sunshine while you work your yard. Here are some tips to make your lawn and garden the envy of your neighborhood.

![Mold](//images.ctfassets.net/e0821f6q5nel/3X6HeRtberZjSR1Vn7FrEr/5aad52f3b70da054fa2e96c05a71f36a/Mold.jpg)

## Mowing Tips for Summer

Regular mowing helps maintain a healthy lawn throughout the summer. Proper mowing techniques encourage strong grass growth, prevent disease, and reduce weeds. A consistent mowing schedule, especially during dry periods, helps your lawn stay green even in hot weather. Keeping your mower blades sharp and setting the right mowing height will keep your grass looking lush.

### How Often to Mow Your Lawn

- **Mow Weekly:** Mow your lawn about once a week during the summer. This frequency keeps your lawn at the right height and looking tidy.
- **Adjust for Rain:** If there has been little to no rainfall, it's okay to mow less often to avoid stressing the grass.

### Ideal Grass Height for Summer

- **Optimal Height:** Keep your grass at a height of ¾ to 1½ inches. This range is ideal for most lawns and helps prevent stress and damage.
- **One-Third Rule:** Avoid cutting more than one-third of the grass blade length at a time. Cutting too much can weaken the grass and make it more likely to develop problems.

### Importance of Sharp Mower Blades

- **Clean Cuts:** Keep your mower blades sharp for a clean cut. Dull blades tear the grass, which can cause brown tips and increase the risk of disease.
- **Regular Maintenance:** Sharpen your mower blades at the start of the mowing season and after every 10 to 12 mowings to keep them effective.

Following these mowing tips will help your lawn stay healthy and vibrant all summer, so it looks its best through the hottest months.

## Watering Your Lawn Effectively

Proper watering helps maintain a healthy lawn during the summer. Watering your lawn correctly encourages grass roots to grow deep, making them more resilient to heat and drought. It also keeps the grass looking green and vibrant. Knowing when and how much to water can make all the difference in keeping your lawn lush throughout the summer months.

### Best Time to Water Your Lawn

- **Early Morning:** Water your lawn early in the morning, ideally between 6 a.m. and 10 a.m. This allows the water to soak into the soil before the sun gets too hot, reducing evaporation and helping the grass absorb moisture effectively.
- **Evening Option:** If watering in the morning isn’t possible, late afternoon or early evening is the next best time. Aim for around 4 p.m. to 6 p.m. This gives the lawn enough time to dry before nightfall, which helps reduce the risk of fungal diseases.

### How Much Water Does Your Lawn Need?

- **Deep Watering:** Aim to give your lawn about 1 to 1.5 inches of water per week, including rainfall. This amount lets water reach the roots, promoting deeper growth and making the grass more drought-resistant.
- **Watering Frequency:** Instead of watering lightly every day, water deeply every few days. This practice encourages the grass to develop deep roots, which are more resilient during dry spells.

### Tips for Efficient Watering

- **Avoid Overwatering:** Overwatering can lead to shallow roots and increase the risk of lawn diseases. Check the soil moisture before watering by sticking a screwdriver or a similar tool into the soil. If it goes in easily, the lawn likely has enough moisture.
- **Use Sprinklers Wisely:** If using a sprinkler, set a timer to prevent overwatering. Choose a sprinkler that distributes water evenly across the lawn to make sure all areas get adequate hydration.

By following these watering tips, your lawn can stay healthy and green, even during the hottest parts of summer. Proper watering not only improves grass health but also conserves water, making your lawn care routine more efficient and sustainable.

## Mulching and Weed Control

Mulching and effective weed control are key practices for maintaining soil health and keeping your garden free of unwanted growth. Mulch provides numerous benefits, including moisture retention, soil temperature regulation, and weed suppression. Pairing mulch with proper weed management helps create a healthy environment for your plants to thrive.

### Benefits of Mulching

- **Weed Suppression:** A layer of mulch helps block sunlight from reaching weed seeds, reducing their chances of germination. This makes it easier to keep your garden beds clean and free of weeds.
- **Moisture Retention:** Mulch helps the soil retain moisture by slowing evaporation. This is especially important during the hot summer months when water can evaporate quickly from exposed soil.
- **Soil Health:** Organic mulch, such as wood chips or shredded leaves, gradually decomposes and adds nutrients back into the soil, improving its overall health and fertility.
- **Erosion Prevention:** Mulch helps prevent soil erosion by breaking the impact of rain and irrigation, which protects plant roots and keeps soil in place.

### Mulching Tips

- **Apply Correctly:** Use 2 to 3 inches of mulch around your plants. A thicker layer may prevent water and air from reaching the roots, while a thinner layer may not be as effective at suppressing weeds.
- **Avoid Plastic:** Do not use plastic sheeting under mulch. It can prevent nutrients from reaching the soil and restrict water flow.
- **Choose Quality Mulch:** Purchase mulch from a reliable source to avoid introducing weed seeds or contaminants into your garden.

### Practical Weed Control Tips

- **Timing Matters:** Weeding after a rain or watering makes it easier to pull weeds out by the roots. If the soil is dry, use a hoe or hand weeder to cut weeds just below the surface.
- **Stay Consistent:** Regular weeding prevents weeds from going to seed and spreading throughout your garden. Aim to weed at least once a week during the growing season.
- **Target Young Weeds:** Remove weeds when they are young and have not yet established deep root systems. This makes them easier to pull and reduces their ability to compete with your plants for nutrients and water.

By combining mulching with effective weed control, you can maintain a healthy garden that supports plant growth and minimizes the need for constant maintenance. These practices help create a thriving garden environment that looks great and supports healthy plant development.

## Planting and Pest Control

Selecting the right plants and managing pests naturally are vital for maintaining a healthy and productive garden. By choosing fast-growing summer plants suited to your climate and using natural pest deterrents, you can create a thriving garden that requires less maintenance and promotes biodiversity. 

### Choosing Fast-Growing Summer Plants

- **Vegetables:** For a productive vegetable garden, consider planting fast-growing summer vegetables like beans, cucumbers, corn, and beets. These plants thrive in warm weather and can provide a bountiful harvest throughout the season.
- **Herbs:** Herbs such as basil, oregano, thyme, and sage grow quickly in the summer and add fresh flavors to your cooking. They also attract beneficial insects that help keep pests at bay.
- **Flowers:** Add vibrant color to your garden with summer-blooming flowers like marigolds, asters, black-eyed Susans, blanket flowers, and zinnias. These flowers are not only beautiful but also attract pollinators, which can improve the health and yield of your garden.

### Tips for Successful Planting

- **Know Your Climate:** Choose plants that are well-suited to your local climate. Native plants are often the best choice because they are adapted to the region's weather conditions and soil, making them easier to grow and maintain.
- **Stagger Planting Times:** To enjoy a continuous harvest, plant different crops at staggered intervals. This approach ensures that you always have something fresh to pick throughout the summer.

### Natural Pest Control Methods

- **Attract Beneficial Insects:** Planting specific herbs and flowers can attract insects that prey on common garden pests. Coriander, dill, spearmint, garlic, marigolds, and yarrow are great choices for attracting ladybugs and lacewings, which feed on aphids, mites, mealybugs, and other harmful insects.
- **Companion Planting:** Use companion planting techniques to naturally deter pests. For example, planting marigolds alongside tomatoes can help repel nematodes, while basil planted near peppers can deter aphids.
- **Maintain Garden Health:** Healthy plants are less likely to suffer from pest infestations. Regularly check your plants for signs of damage or stress, and address any issues promptly to keep your garden thriving.

By selecting the right plants and using natural pest control methods, you can create a beautiful and productive garden that requires less intervention and supports a healthy ecosystem. These strategies not only help protect your plants but also promote a sustainable gardening environment.

## Tool Maintenance and Garden Prep

Taking care of your gardening tools and preparing your garden for the next season are important steps for keeping your outdoor space in great shape. [Regular maintenance extends the life of your equipment](/maintain/lawn-and-garden) and helps make gardening more effective. Preparing for fall involves transitioning your garden and planning for the cooler months ahead.

### Maintaining Your Gardening Tools

- **Clean After Use:** Scrub your gardening tools with warm, soapy water to remove dirt and debris. Rinse them thoroughly and let them air dry to prevent rust.
- **Smooth Wood Handles:** Sand any rough patches on wooden handles to prevent splinters and improve grip. This simple step makes your tools safer and more comfortable to use.
- **Oil Your Tools:** Apply a light coating of oil to metal parts to protect them from rust and keep them working smoothly. Use a non-petroleum-based oil on wood handles to maintain their condition and prevent cracking.

### Deadheading and Garden Maintenance

- **Remove Spent Blooms:** Regularly deadhead your plants by removing dead or fading blooms. This practice encourages new growth and keeps your garden looking vibrant throughout the season.
- **Tidy Up:** Keep your garden beds clean by removing fallen leaves, weeds, and other debris. This not only improves the appearance of your garden but also helps reduce pests and diseases.

### Preparing Your Garden for Fall

- **Plant Cool-Weather Crops:** As summer winds down, consider planting cool-weather crops like broccoli, carrots, lettuce, and spinach. These vegetables thrive in cooler temperatures and can provide a harvest well into the autumn months.
- **Plan for Perennials:** Take note of which perennials performed well this summer and consider dividing or moving them to optimize garden space for next year.
- **Transitioning Your Lawn:** Late summer is also a good time to prepare your lawn for fall. Consider aerating your lawn and applying a slow-release fertilizer to strengthen grass roots before winter.

### Riding Mower Maintenance and Repair

For those with riding mowers, keeping your equipment in good condition is key to maintaining a beautiful lawn. Regular tasks, such as sharpening blades and checking oil levels, help produce clean cuts and healthy grass.

- **Schedule Maintenance:** To keep your riding mower running smoothly, **schedule regular maintenance with Sears Home Services**. This will help prevent breakdowns and extend the life of your mower. [Schedule your riding mower maintenance with Sears Home Services](/maintain/lawn-and-garden).

- **Repair Services:** If you encounter any issues with your mower, address them promptly. For professional help with any repairs, consider scheduling [lawn repair near you](/repair/riding-mower-repair-service) with one of our experts to get your equipment back in working order.

By taking care of your tools and preparing your garden for the changing seasons, you can enjoy a healthy and beautiful outdoor space year-round. Regular maintenance and planning ahead keep yo
